At 21:58 12/07/2005, you wrote:


> >This is a good way to increase the situations considered.
> >But my view (which you probably know :) would be that we need a way of
> >setting up the networks to be rotationally invariant before they would have
> >much chance of finding the "essence" of the game.
> >
> >
>I'm not sure I understand this point. Are you hinting at some higher
>level representation of the game where rotation is factored out.
>Interesting, but if I have to construct complex representation models
>for every problem I approach, then that takes a lot of the fun out of
>the idea that I can just throw together a reasonably simple/sensible
>model and go do something else while NEAT does the hard work for me!

Sort of.  All I really mean is that all rotations and transforms of a board 
are actually identical and have the same correct move.  So there is no need 
for your net to learn them each separately.  I've need doing to analysis of 
TTT and to avoid processing identical boards twice I've simply:

1) define each board as a base-3 code number (top-left is first digit, 
top-middle is second..., empty = 0, cross = 1, naught = 2)
2) when a board appears calculate than number for each of its 8 transforms
3) then file and process the board only under the _lowest_ of those codes

So the simplest way I would remove mirroring and rotation from a network's 
consideration would be just to do the same thing.  Always transform the 
board to its lowest coded variant before showing it to the network.  Of 
course, this is assuming your networks are state-driven off only the 
current board and don't remember their previous moves...

> >Damn, you motivated me, I want to work on this now!
> >
> >
>Sorry.

That's not a bad thing :)

> >I'd like to work in C++, what NEAT version would be best.  Just scanning
> >the list there's Ken's and Mat's.  I'm generally on Windows, OTOH I don't
> >especially care about graphics for this, so....
> >
> >
>Hey look, I just spent a day of my life chasing correct combinations of
>unix packages to build mono, which just re-affirms my faith in Java and
>.Net - you can actually get on and do what you want to do, instead of
>scanning google for references to some obscure error from a makefile or
>config script! [takes deep breath... and relax]  ;)

Not sure I follow you here.  But C++ is my language and if I were to switch 
to another I would probably want something really different like python or 
lisp....

[...]

Another angle is that my (brief) studies show only 746 unique boards that 
can come up in TTT.  135 of them are winning positions and 3 are stalemates 
(that seems low, I'll check it later) so that leaves only 608 that the 
network needs to generate a move for.  And there is one or more correct 
answer(s) for each (at least if we include "resign" for those where we know 
we already lost).  So how about ordering those 608 in reverse order of how 
"simple" they are to answer and then just testing the network against each 
of those in order, the score being the number of boards the network gets 
through before giving a wrong answer.

I know this may not seem in the spirit of what you're after.  e.g. just 
chasing the perfect game and ignoring any question of alternative 
strategies along the way, but the fact that it would be possible to chase 
the perfect game in this way might suggest that there may be no alternative 
strategies to find.  e.g. that the game is too simple...

         Ian

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
